title: Oral Health and Systemic Diseases
content: The work focuses on the value of integrating dental services into other healthcare and public health settings. The importance of oral hygiene to overall health, and the association of poor oral health and systemic diseases like cancer and diabetes is discussed. Tooth decay, oral hygiene in children, the utility of dental products, and ideal oral care regimens for different populations are addressed. Issues specific to immunocompromised patients and those with chronic illnesses are also discussed.

title: Anatomy and Health of Teeth
content: Anatomy of teeth and the purpose of the dental pulp—a highly vascularized and innervated region of the tooth. Types of teeth and the different purpose they serve. Anatomy of the oral cavity, bacteria in the mouth, and what a healthy mouth looks like.

title: Oral Hygiene Practices
content: Detrimental effects of sugar and the importance of fluoride and oral hygiene. Oral health challenges for cancer patients and immunocompromised people. The oral health risks associated with human papilloma virus (HPV). Periodontal disease: caries and root canals. The relationship between poor oral health and systemic health diseases. Potential connection between oral hygiene and COVID-19. Dry mouth leading to oral infections and ways to prevent it.

title: Dental Care and Products
content: What determines the appearance of teeth, methods of teeth whitening, and whether you should remove mercury fillings. Importance of fluoride for preventing tooth decay, and dental care for children. Useful dental products: floss, electrics toothbrushes, and more. Ideal oral care regimens.

title: Optimizing Brain Health
content: Alzheimer's disease including the possibility of a vascular hypothesis as well as the factors that can impact disease risk such as type 2 diabetes, blood pressure, omega supplementation, exercise, sauna, and more. The role of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA and DHA) in brain health and prevention of neurodegeneration. Blood pressure: an important modifiable lifestyle factor that can affect Alzheimer's disease risk. Possible mechanisms by which exercise reduces the risk of Alzheimer's disease. The relationship between cardiorespiratory fitness and dementia risk. How exercise may reduce the risk of cancer. Impact of alcohol consumption on breast cancer risk and overall health. Exercise as an intervention for poor sleep habits. The longevity benefits of consuming adequate protein and strength training to preserve muscle mass and strength. Fasting: weighing the risk vs. reward.

title: Preventing Cardiovascular Disease
content: The latest in diagnostic imaging, blood pressure, metabolic health, and more.

title: Weight Loss Drugs and Geroprotective Agents
content: Pros and cons of GLP-1 weight loss drugs and metformin as a geroprotective agent.

title: Oral Health
content: Anatomy of teeth and the purpose of the dental pulp—a highly vascularized and innervated region of the tooth. The role of the nervous connection and vascular supply to the tooth. Tooth decay first affects the pulp. If you excise the pulp, you can preserve the root. Try not to extract teeth because the space they hold is important. If necessary, do a root canal or put in an artificial crown. Put implants in if you have to extract an entire tooth; not as good as a real tooth but can still hold the space and provide some function. Can still get inflammatory periodontal disease with an implant.

title: Teeth and Their Functions
content: Incisors and laterals are used for cutting and have a single root. Canines are very strong with longer roots, used for tearing apart food. Premolars and bicuspids, of which there are 4 each in both upper and lower jaw, start to break down food. Molars are used for chewing and there are 6 in the upper and 6 in the lower jaw. Second premolars have two roots, while molars have three or four depending on how big the tooth is.

title: Importance of Chewing and Saliva in Digestion
content: The digestive process starts in the mouth. Chewing is key because it brings the food in contact with saliva to start digestion. Saliva plays a protective role. When patients have dry mouth, the oral microbiome is altered. The constant washing and flushing maintain microbiome homeostasis and prevent buildup of harmful bacteria.

title: Oral Hygiene and Bacteria
content: Oral hygiene is the key to oral health and regular brushing makes you healthier. There are aerobic, anaerobic, and facultative bacteria in the mouth. Over 700 different bacteria live in symbiosis in the human mouth without causing disease. However, changes in abundance and diversity can lead to overgrowth of harmful bacteria and suppression of beneficial bacteria.

title: Periodontal Disease
content: Periodontal disease starts with inflammation around the gums. In healthy people, the periodontal ligament is tight. If brushing is stopped, gums get inflamed and will bleed if flossing is resumed. At the initial stage of periodontal disease, it’s highly modifiable. But if disease continues to develop, the ligament gets inflamed and will detach from the tooth, allowing bacteria in. Ligaments deteriorate and form a pocket, culminating in bone loss.

title: Effects of Sugar and Importance of Fluoride
content: Fructose, sucrose, lactose, small complex starches are all harmful to dental health. Most drinks have added sugar. Cariogenic bacteria metabolize the sugar for extra energy, secrete acid which destroys the enamel of the tooth. Toothpaste is the main source of fluoride which hardens the enamel and protects against cavities, especially in children.

title: Oral Health Challenges for Cancer Patients
content: Patient undergoing radiation treatment have mouth ulcers that make it painful to eat, drink, or brush their teeth. They are immunocompromised in general and also have increased susceptibility to infection from the loss of the immune barrier in the mouth. They also often have dry mouth from the treatment, and some cannot produce saliva anymore. They get fungal infections, which escalates a lot of local infection and inflammation in the oral cavity and affects them systemically.

title: Oral Health Risks Associated with HPV
content: HPV is believed to cause 70% of cancers of the oropharynx in the US. It’s unknown if HPV infection alone can cause oropharyngeal cancers or if other risk factors (such as tobacco use) must also be present. Most (~90%) HPV-related oropharyngeal cancers are positive for a specific strain called HPV-16. Oral sex is the primary mode of transmission, and there may also be other unknown ways.

title: Oral Health and Infections
content: Mouth infections are about the balance of various microbes. Some, like P. gingivalis, allow virus to grow. Immune system deficiency also allows viruses, bacteria, and fungi to develop into infections.

title: HPV Vaccine and Oropharyngeal Cancers
content: The HPV vaccine protects against the types of HPV that can cause oropharyngeal cancers. The CDC currently recommends that everyone be vaccinated around age 11-12 (and through age 26 years if not already vaccinated).

title: Periodontal Disease and Dental Decay
content: The initial stage of dental decay is breaking through the enamel. When it reaches the dentin, it’s painful and cold sensitive. Once an infection reaches the pulp, a root canal is required. Root canal treatment is essentially a microscopic surgery.

title: Oral Health and Systemic Diseases
content: Periodontal disease has been associated low birth weight, heart problems, and diabetes. Some markers of periodontal disease and Alzheimer’s disease are similar. Poor oral health leads to poor or substandard amounts of inflammatory environment, and that’s the driver of these diseases.

title: Oral Hygiene and COVID-19
content: COVID is transmitted by saliva / the mouth. Periodontal disease would be the perfect reservoir for the virus. Oral hygiene should be a priority for these patients.

title: Dry Mouth and Oral Infections
content: Dry mouth can result in oral infections. It can be a result of poor oral hygiene (and certain medications) that allows opportunistic species (sometimes both virus and fungus) to grow. Keeping mouth lubricated with SUGAR FREE chewing gum or lozenges can be useful for people who have dry mouth. Continual hydration is also key.

title: Teeth Whitening and Mercury Fillings
content: Whitening the teeth can be detrimental if bleach excessively and cause mineral loss. There is no need to remove mercury fillings if there is no decay underneath. The mercury in fillings is not harmful.

title: Importance of Fluoride and Dental Care for Children
content: Fluoride is important for preventing tooth decay. Want to use toothpaste with 1000-1500 parts per million (ppm) of fluoride. Night is an important time for tooth decay. It's critical to brush before you go to bed.

title: Useful Dental Products
content: Dental floss is even more important than brushing. You can’t really clean the plaque that is in between your teeth. Anaerobic bacteria that cause systemic health problems like cardiovascular disease and diabetes are found in niches without oxygen like in between teeth and the back of the throat.

title: Oral Care Regimens
content: It can stimulate the gums but it cannot substitute for flossing. Electric toothbrushes, Sonicare and Oral B are equally effective. Use whichever you prefer. Ideal oral care regimens include brushing teeth in the morning only after drinking coffee and then eating around 11. Use an Oral B toothbrush for 30 seconds on top inside, 30 seconds top outside, and then same on the bottom. Use a toothpick during the day. After dinner, floss and then use the Oral B again (with a xylitol-based fluoride toothpaste). Do not use mouthwash or a Waterpik. Brush after coffee to clean the mouth from overnight. Soft bristle toothbrushes can be better for the tongue. Rinse your toothbrush after using it, and then dry it because bacteria thrive in moisture. Rinse in warm water. You can even rinse with soap.

title: Mouthwash and Microbiome
content: Mouthwash wipes out all your microbiome, including the good ones. It's good to use when can’t brush, but don’t overuse so microbes won’t become resistant. There is not good data on whether mouthwash can cause fungal or other overgrowth. But it changes the microflora, so if you’re healthy you don’t want to interfere with it.

title: Prevention and Dental Checkups
content: The take-home message is that prevention is key. The only way to prevent dental caries throughout life is chronic preventive oral care. Go to the dentist every 6 months for a cleaning and to ensure no cavities. Research shows 6 months is good for healthy people. If you are high risk with systemic health problems (e.g., diabetes), maybe 3 times a year instead.

title: Periodontal Disease and Systemic Health
content: The rate of progression of periodontal disease varies. It’s closely tied to the body, so a systemic issue will exacerbate inflammation. Worse periodontal disease is seen in patients with systemic diseases.

title: Oral Hygiene and Diabetes
content: Diabetics have more periodontal disease, so need more frequent cleanings. Both Type I (T1DM) and Type II (T2DM) diabetes are associated with periodontal disease. Both types of diabetes involve increased inflammation and reactive oxygen species (ROS) in the gingiva. Hyperglycemia (high blood sugar), high levels of advanced glycation end products (AGEs), and possibly hypoinsulinemia (low blood insulin) or insulin resistance may all contribute. The largest clinical trial addressing this question did not find any effects of periodontal treatment on improving glycemic control [as measured by glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c)] in patients with T2DM. But both diabetes and periodontal disease are preventable, so that is the key.
